transcript.speaker: Sarah Kim
transcript.text: Alright, thanks for coming in today James. I'm Sarah Kim, Engineering Manager here at Nexus. I've got your resume pulled up and I'm really excited to chat.

transcript.speaker: Sarah Kim
transcript.text: Let me also introduce David Cho, one of our senior staff engineers who'll be sitting in for the panel portion.

transcript.speaker: David Cho
transcript.text: Hey James, good to meet you. I'll mostly be listening and jumping in with some technical questions later.

transcript.speaker: James Park
transcript.text: Thanks Sarah, thanks David. Really glad to be here. I've been following Nexus for a while now. The distributed systems work you're doing is right up my alley.

transcript.speaker: Sarah Kim
transcript.text: Great to hear. So let's start with your background. Can you walk us through your experience with large-scale distributed systems?

transcript.speaker: James Park
transcript.text: Absolutely. I've been working in backend infrastructure for about 8 years now. Most recently at Stratum, I was the tech lead on their real-time data pipeline.

transcript.speaker: James Park
transcript.text: We were processing around 2 million events per second across 400 nodes. The system had to maintain sub-50 millisecond latency at the 99th percentile.

transcript.speaker: Sarah Kim
transcript.text: That's impressive scale. What was the most challenging aspect of maintaining that latency target?

transcript.speaker: James Park
transcript.text: Honestly, it was the tail latency. Getting P50 down is relatively straightforward, but P99 is a different beast. We had to redesign our partitioning strategy three times.

transcript.speaker: James Park
transcript.text: The key insight was moving to a consistent hashing scheme with virtual nodes. That eliminated the hot partition problem that was causing our tail latency spikes.

transcript.speaker: Sarah Kim
transcript.text: That's a solid approach. Now, your resume mentions you led a team of 12 engineers at Stratum. Can you tell me about that experience?

transcript.speaker: James Park
transcript.text: Right, so I was leading a team of about 15 engineers. We were split into three squads: ingest, processing, and storage.

transcript.speaker: David Cho
transcript.text: Just a quick note, James. Your resume says 12 engineers, but you just mentioned 15. Could you clarify that?

transcript.speaker: James Park
transcript.text: Oh, good catch. So it started as 12 when I first took on the lead role, and we grew to 15 over the two years. I should have been clearer about that.

transcript.speaker: Sarah Kim
transcript.text: No worries, growth is a good thing. Let's move into system design. I'd like you to design a real-time notification system that can handle 500,000 concurrent users.

transcript.speaker: James Park
transcript.text: Great problem. Let me think about this from the top down. First, we need to consider the connection layer. For 500K concurrent users, I'd go with WebSocket connections behind a load balancer.

transcript.speaker: James Park
transcript.text: We'd need roughly 50 WebSocket servers assuming each can handle about 10,000 connections. Each server maintains a local connection registry.

transcript.speaker: James Park
transcript.text: For the messaging layer, I'd use a pub-sub system. Kafka would be my choice here because of its durability guarantees and replay capability.

transcript.speaker: David Cho
transcript.text: Why Kafka over something lighter like Redis pub-sub? For notifications, do you really need the durability overhead?

transcript.speaker: James Park
transcript.text: That's a fair challenge. For pure real-time with no delivery guarantees, Redis pub-sub would be fine. But in my experience, users expect notifications to be reliable.

transcript.speaker: James Park
transcript.text: If a user is temporarily disconnected and reconnects, they should see missed notifications. Kafka's consumer offsets give us that for free. With Redis you'd need to build that yourself.

transcript.speaker: David Cho
transcript.text: Good reasoning. How would you handle the fanout problem? Say one event needs to notify 100,000 users.

transcript.speaker: James Park
transcript.text: For high-fanout scenarios, I'd use a two-tier approach. Hot topics with many subscribers get their own dedicated Kafka partitions. We'd pre-compute the subscriber lists and fan out at the WebSocket server level.

transcript.speaker: James Park
transcript.text: The key metric I'd target is end-to-end delivery under 200 milliseconds for P95. That includes Kafka produce, consume, and WebSocket push.

transcript.speaker: Sarah Kim
transcript.text: Solid design. Let's shift gears to coding philosophy. How do you approach code reviews?

transcript.speaker: James Park
transcript.text: I believe code reviews are the single most important engineering practice. They're not just about catching bugs, they're about knowledge sharing and maintaining consistency.

transcript.speaker: James Park
transcript.text: At Stratum, I introduced a rule that no PR ships without at least two approvals, and one has to be from someone outside your immediate squad.

transcript.speaker: James Park
transcript.text: That cross-squad review really helped break down silos. Before that, we had three different error handling patterns across the codebase. Within a quarter, we converged on one.

transcript.speaker: Sarah Kim
transcript.text: I love that approach. We actually have a similar philosophy here. What about testing? How do you think about test coverage?

transcript.speaker: James Park
transcript.text: I'm a big advocate for testing at the right level. I don't obsess over coverage percentages. 80% coverage with well-designed tests beats 95% coverage with brittle unit tests every time.

transcript.speaker: James Park
transcript.text: For distributed systems specifically, I invest heavily in integration tests and chaos testing. We ran weekly game days at Stratum where we'd inject failures into production-like environments.

transcript.speaker: David Cho
transcript.text: Weekly game days, that's commitment. What was the most interesting failure mode you discovered through those?

transcript.speaker: James Park
transcript.text: We found that when three specific Kafka brokers went down simultaneously, our consumer group rebalancing took 45 seconds instead of the expected 5. That would have been catastrophic in production.

transcript.speaker: James Park
transcript.text: Turned out it was a configuration issue with session timeouts. Five-minute fix once we found it, but it would have been a P0 incident if we hadn't caught it.

transcript.speaker: Sarah Kim
transcript.text: Let's talk about culture fit. What kind of engineering culture do you thrive in?

transcript.speaker: James Park
transcript.text: I do my best work in environments with high trust and low bureaucracy. I want to be able to ship fast but also have the discipline to do things right.

transcript.speaker: James Park
transcript.text: I'm big on documentation. I know engineers hate writing docs, but I believe an undocumented system is a ticking time bomb. At Stratum, I set up a culture where every design decision goes through an RFC process.

transcript.speaker: Sarah Kim
transcript.text: That resonates deeply with us. We actually just implemented an RFC process last quarter. What about work-life balance?

transcript.speaker: James Park
transcript.text: I'm a firm believer in sustainable pace. Crunch time happens, but it shouldn't be the norm. I've seen teams burn out from chronic overtime, and the code quality always suffers.

transcript.speaker: James Park
transcript.text: I also care about mentorship. Helping junior engineers grow is one of the most rewarding parts of being a senior engineer. At Stratum, I set up a structured mentorship program for new hires.

transcript.speaker: David Cho
transcript.text: That's great to hear. Quick technical question to close out: if you had to pick one technology you're most excited about right now, what would it be?

transcript.speaker: James Park
transcript.text: Without hesitation, it's eBPF. The ability to run sandboxed programs in the kernel without modifying kernel source code is a game changer for observability.

transcript.speaker: James Park
transcript.text: We used it at Stratum for network-level tracing and it gave us visibility we never had before. I'd love to bring that expertise here.

transcript.speaker: Sarah Kim
transcript.text: That's actually something we've been exploring. This has been a great conversation, James. Let me outline next steps.

transcript.speaker: Sarah Kim
transcript.text: We'd like to bring you back for a follow-up session with the VP of Engineering. I'll also need to set up a reference check. And David, could you prepare a brief technical assessment for James?

transcript.speaker: David Cho
transcript.text: Absolutely. I'll put together a take-home that focuses on distributed systems design. Should take about two hours.

transcript.speaker: James Park
transcript.text: Sounds great. I'm really excited about the opportunity. Thanks for your time today, both of you.

transcript.speaker: Sarah Kim
transcript.text: Thank you James. We'll be in touch early next week. Have a great rest of your day.

WebSocket connections with 50 servers

Two-tier fanout for high-subscriber topics

Two-approval code review policy with cross-squad reviews
Prefers well-designed tests over high coverage numbers
Weekly chaos testing game days
Discovered critical Kafka rebalancing bug
Values high trust and low bureaucracy
Strong advocate for documentation and RFCs
Believes in sustainable pace over crunch
Passionate about mentorship
Excited about eBPF for observability

insights.summary: Technical interview for a Senior Engineer position at Nexus, conducted by Sarah Kim (Engineering Manager) with David Cho (Senior Staff Engineer) on the panel. Candidate James Park demonstrated strong distributed systems expertise with 8 years of experience, including leading a real-time data pipeline processing 2M events/sec at Stratum. He delivered a solid system design for a notification system and showed strong coding philosophy around code reviews and chaos testing. A minor discrepancy was noted between his resume (12 engineers) and verbal statement (15 engineers), which he clarified as team growth. The panel decided to advance him to a follow-up interview with the VP of Engineering.

contradictions.explanation: James Park's resume states he led a team of 12 engineers, but during the interview he said 15. When flagged by David Cho, James clarified the team started at 12 and grew to 15 over two years. While the explanation is reasonable, the resume should be updated to reflect the accurate range. This minor inconsistency was caught by the panel.
